name: microdesktop: overlapping
description:
1-bit nostalgia artwork based on the early era of graphical user interface. Historical painting where the first personal computer desktop is the subject.

The overlapping windows were an important part of the user interface design of the first Macintosh, first introduced on the Lisa in 1983. Neither the Alto Star nor the first version of Windows could overlap windows or other UI elements. (But the Alto prototype could). It was possible thanks to clever redraw routines and the region data structure.

You can learn more about it here: https://www.folklore.org/StoryView.py?project=Macintosh&story=I_Still_Remember_Regions.txt&topic=QuickDraw

The microdesktop series is inspired by the black and white interface of the first Macintosh in 1984 and its small 512 × 342 pixels, black and white (no greys), 9" screen.

Designer and artists had to use every pixels and find ways around the limitations, leading to beautiful 1-bit icons, backgrounds and illustrations.

The original resolution of this piece is 10 times smaller than the original Macintosh desktop at 51 × 34 pixels only. The actual final image file is scaled up 8 times, to be visible on modern computers.
